p: Changes in global temperature are accompanied by certain changes in precipitation patterns, enhancing the risk of climate induced extreme events like floods [ 57], droughts [ 58], tropical cyclones [ 59], and frequent heat waves. In an agrarian economy like that of India, the agricultural production sector still provides 50% of the employment opportunities and contributes up to 14% of the total gross domestic product (GDP) of the country. About 43% of the total geographic area is being used for agricultural purposes in the country, and about 60% of the net sown area is still rainfed [ 60]. Agriculture in India is highly sensitive to climate change impacts [ 61â€“ 65]. For example, factors, such as a high dependence on monsoons, small land holdings, and excessive reliance on fertilizers, contribute to the existing vulnerability of the Indian agricultural sector.
